"**You 're So Vain**" is a song written in 1971 by [Carly
Simon](/wiki/Carly_Simon "Carly Simon") and released in November 1972. The
song is a critical profile of a self-absorbed lover about whom Simon asserts
"You're so vain, you probably think this song is about you." The title
subject's identity has long been a matter of speculation, with Simon stating
that the song refers to three men, only one of whom she has named publicly,
actor [Warren Beatty](/wiki/Warren_Beatty "Warren Beatty").[3] The song is
ranked at #92 on _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard
\(magazine\)")_ 's Greatest Songs of All-Time.[4] "You're So Vain" was voted
#216 in [RIAA](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording
Industry Association of America")'s [Songs of the
Century](/wiki/Songs_of_the_Century "Songs of the Century"), and in August
2014, the UK's [Official Charts Company](/wiki/Official_Charts_Company
"Official Charts Company") crowned it the ultimate song of the 1970s.[5]

The distinctive [bass guitar](/wiki/Bass_guitar "Bass guitar") intro is played
by [Klaus Voormann](/wiki/Klaus_Voormann "Klaus Voormann").[6] The strings
were arranged by Simon and orchestrated by [Paul
Buckmaster](/wiki/Paul_Buckmaster "Paul Buckmaster"). Simon plays piano on the
track.

## Subject of the
song[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27re_So_Vain&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Subject of the song")]

Before the song became a hit single in 1972, Simon told an interviewer that
the song was about "men," not a specific "man".[7]

In 1983, she said it is not about [Mick Jagger](/wiki/Mick_Jagger "Mick
Jagger"),[8] who contributed uncredited [backing
vocals](/wiki/Backing_vocalist "Backing vocalist") to the song.[9] In a 1993
book, [Angie Bowie](/wiki/Angie_Bowie "Angie Bowie") claimed to be the "wife
of a close friend" mentioned in "You're So Vain", and that Jagger, for a time,
had been "obsessed" with her.[10] Simon made another comment about the
subject's identity as a guest artist on [Janet Jackson](/wiki/Janet_Jackson
"Janet Jackson")'s 2001 single, "[Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is
About You)](/wiki/Son_of_a_Gun_\(I_Betcha_Think_This_Song_Is_About_You\) "Son
of a Gun \(I Betcha Think This Song Is About You\)")", which
[sampled](/wiki/Sampling_\(music\) "Sampling \(music\)") "You're So Vain".
Simon said about the song, "The apricot scarf was worn by Nick
([Delbanco](/wiki/Nicholas_Delbanco "Nicholas Delbanco")). Nothing in the
words referred to Mick."

In a 2007 interview, [Warren Beatty](/wiki/Warren_Beatty "Warren Beatty")
said, "Let's be honest. That song was about me."[11] Simon had said in 1983
that Beatty "certainly thought it was about him — he called me and said thanks
for the song..."[8] In an interview for the 1978/1982 version of _[The History
of Rock and Roll](/wiki/The_History_of_Rock_and_Roll "The History of Rock and
Roll")_ radio series, producer [Richard Perry](/wiki/Richard_Perry "Richard
Perry") acknowledges that Simon was essentially referring to Beatty while also
evoking other previous relationships in her life.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Over the years Simon has divulged "letter clues" and has claimed that the
subject's name contains the letters A, E, and R.[12]

Shortly before the writing of the song, Simon was married to [James
Taylor](/wiki/James_Taylor "James Taylor"); she has said that he was
"definitely not" the subject of the song.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] [David
Bowie](/wiki/David_Bowie "David Bowie"), [David Cassidy](/wiki/David_Cassidy
"David Cassidy") and [Cat Stevens](/wiki/Cat_Stevens "Cat Stevens") have all
been cited by the press as speculative candidates.[13][14][15]

In August 2003 Simon agreed to reveal the name of the song's subject to the
highest bidder of the [Martha's Vineyard](/wiki/Martha%27s_Vineyard "Martha's
Vineyard") Possible Dreams charity auction. With the top bid of $50,000, [Dick
Ebersol](/wiki/Dick_Ebersol "Dick Ebersol"), president of [NBC
Sports](/wiki/NBC_Sports "NBC Sports") and a friend of Simon, won the right to
know the name of the subject of "You're So Vain". A condition of the prize was
that Ebersol not reveal the name.[16] Ebersol said Simon allowed him to
divulge a clue about the person's name: "Carly told me that I could offer up
to the entire world a clue as to what she'll tell me when we have this night
in about two weeks. And the clue is: The letter 'E' is in the person's
name."[17]

In 2004 Simon told [Regis Philbin](/wiki/Regis_Philbin "Regis Philbin"), "If I
tell it, it's going to come out in dribs and drabs. And I've given out two
letters already, an 'A' and an 'E.' But I'm going to add one to it. I'm going
to add an 'R,' in honor of you."[12]

In 2005 Simon's ex-husband Jim Hart said he was sure that the song was not
about anyone famous.[18]

On June 19, 2008, [Howard Stern](/wiki/Howard_Stern "Howard Stern") stated
that Simon had privately revealed to him about whom the song was written after
her interview on his popular radio show on [Sirius Satellite
Radio](/wiki/Sirius_Satellite_Radio "Sirius Satellite Radio"). Stern
commented, "There is an odd aspect to it... he's not that vain." On March 17,
2009, Stern stated that she had said it was a "composite of three people."
Stern repeated this on May 5, 2014, stating, "She takes me aside, pulls me
close, whispers in my ear... three names. She goes, it wasn't one person, it
was three people."[19] Simon herself confirmed that Stern was among "a few
people" that she had given the names to.[20]

In her 2008 book _Girls Like Us_ , author Sheila Weller includes a detailed
account of Simon's love affair with musician [Dan
Armstrong](/wiki/Dan_Armstrong "Dan Armstrong"), and suggests that he was the
inspiration for "You're So Vain." Her heartbreak over eventually losing him
inspired the song "Dan, My Fling," which appears on her first album.[21]
Armstrong's full name, Daniel Kent Armstrong, contains all three letters of
Simon's clue.

On November 4, 2009, Simon said she had hidden the name of the subject in a
certain version of the song. The next day, the program's crew revealed the
name concealed in a back-played whisper:[22] David. Simon denied that the
whisper was "David," saying she had spoken "Ovid" both forwards and backwards,
and that sounded like David.[23] In February 2010, Simon reiterated that the
name of the subject was whispered in a re-recording of "You're So Vain":
"There's a little whisper—and it's the answer to the puzzle."[24] A
representative for Simon confirmed that the name whispered during the song is
"David".[24] Multiple media outlets then speculated that the subject was
Simon's former boss at [Elektra](/wiki/Elektra_Records "Elektra Records"),
[David Geffen](/wiki/David_Geffen "David Geffen").[25] The following day Jim
Hart, Simon's ex-husband and close friend, denied that the song was about
Geffen.[7] Simon said that when she wrote the song in 1971, she had not yet
met Geffen.[26] Simon's publicist also confirmed the song was not about
Geffen, but that there was indeed "a David who is connected to the song in
some way, shape, or form".[7] _[Vanity Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\)
"Vanity Fair \(magazine\)")_ noted that in addition to "David", "Warren" and
an unintelligible name are whispered during the recording.[27]

After her live performance of the song with Simon in July 2013, [Taylor
Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift "Taylor Swift") stated that Simon had revealed the
identity of the song's subject to her in confidence.[28]

In November 2015, Simon, promoting her about-to-be-published memoir, said, "I
have confirmed that the second verse is Warren (Beatty)" and added that while
"Warren thinks the whole thing is about him," he is the subject of that verse
only, with the remainder of the song referring to two other, still unnamed
men.[3]

## References in the
song[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27re_So_Vain&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: References in the song")]

  * [Gavotte](/wiki/Gavotte "Gavotte") — used in the line "You had one eye in the mirror as you watched yourself gavotte" — is a French kissing dance. In this context it can be taken to mean moving in a pretentious manner.[29]
  * Simon said the line "clouds in my coffee" came "from an airplane flight that I took with Billy Mernit, who was my friend and piano player at the time. As I got my coffee, there were clouds outside the window of the airplane and you could see the reflection in the cup of coffee. Billy said to me, 'Look at the clouds in your coffee'."[30]
  * The line "I hear you went up to Saratoga and your horse naturally won" refers to the [Saratoga Race Course](/wiki/Saratoga_Race_Course "Saratoga Race Course") horse-racing season held in late July, August, and early September in [Saratoga Springs, New York](/wiki/Saratoga_Springs,_New_York "Saratoga Springs, New York"). The season is frequented by the rich and famous of New York and other East Coast cities.[31]
  * Two [solar eclipses](/wiki/Solar_eclipse "Solar eclipse") ("Then you flew your Lear jet up to [Nova Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova Scotia") to see the total eclipse of the sun") were visible from Nova Scotia in the early 1970s, on [March 7, 1970](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_7,_1970 "Solar eclipse of March 7, 1970"),[32] and [July 10, 1972](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_10,_1972 "Solar eclipse of July 10, 1972").[33] Simon said she wrote the song in 1971, but the 1972 eclipse (which could only be seen in Nova Scotia as opposed to the 1970 eclipse which traversed the entire East Coast, and also happened during the Saratoga racing season) better fits the narrative.

## Later versions and
adaptations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27re_So_Vain&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Later versions and adaptations")]

  * The song has been recorded by [Chocolate Starfish](/wiki/Chocolate_Starfish "Chocolate Starfish"), [The Mountain Goats](/wiki/The_Mountain_Goats "The Mountain Goats"), [David Axelrod](/wiki/David_Axelrod_\(musician\) "David Axelrod \(musician\)"), [John Barrowman](/wiki/John_Barrowman "John Barrowman"), [Liza Minnelli](/wiki/Liza_Minnelli "Liza Minnelli"), [Jack Klugman](/wiki/Jack_Klugman "Jack Klugman") and [Tony Randall](/wiki/Tony_Randall "Tony Randall") (as ["The Odd Couple"](/wiki/The_Odd_Couple_\(1970_TV_series\) "The Odd Couple \(1970 TV series\)")), Chimira, Venice, [The Feeling](/wiki/The_Feeling "The Feeling"), [Jann Arden](/wiki/Jann_Arden "Jann Arden"), [Janet Jackson](/wiki/Janet_Jackson "Janet Jackson") (who sampled the song in "[Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is About You)](/wiki/Son_of_a_Gun_\(I_Betcha_Think_This_Song_Is_About_You\) "Son of a Gun \(I Betcha Think This Song Is About You\)")", with Simon providing featured vocals), [Trey Songz](/wiki/Trey_Songz "Trey Songz") (who sampled from Janet Jackson in his single "About You)," [Anna Waronker](/wiki/Anna_Waronker "Anna Waronker"), [Faster Pussycat](/wiki/Faster_Pussycat "Faster Pussycat"), [Dres](/wiki/Dres_\(rapper\) "Dres \(rapper\)"), [Daryll-Ann](/wiki/Daryll-Ann "Daryll-Ann"), [Smokie](/wiki/Smokie_\(band\) "Smokie \(band\)"), [Sally Seltmann](/wiki/Sally_Seltmann "Sally Seltmann"), [Asaro and Wolcott](/wiki/Donald_Wolcott#Current_work "Donald Wolcott"), [Matthew Sweet](/wiki/Matthew_Sweet "Matthew Sweet") and [Susanna Hoffs](/wiki/Susanna_Hoffs "Susanna Hoffs"), [Marilyn Manson](/wiki/Marilyn_Manson_\(band\) "Marilyn Manson \(band\)") (featuring [Johnny Depp](/wiki/Johnny_Depp "Johnny Depp")),[34] and Italian pop star [Mina](/wiki/Mina_Mazzini "Mina Mazzini") in her 1985 album _[Finalmente ho conosciuto il conte Dracula...](/wiki/Finalmente_ho_conosciuto_il_conte_Dracula... "Finalmente ho conosciuto il conte Dracula...")_.
  * [Foo Fighters](/wiki/Foo_Fighters "Foo Fighters") performed the song live at the [50th Annual Grammy Awards](/wiki/50th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "50th Annual Grammy Awards") in 2008.
  * On July 27, 2013, Simon performed "You're So Vain" with [Taylor Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift "Taylor Swift") on her [Red Tour](/wiki/Red_Tour "Red Tour").[35]
  * The song "[Starfuckers, Inc.](/wiki/Starfuckers,_Inc. "Starfuckers, Inc.")" by [Nine Inch Nails](/wiki/Nine_Inch_Nails "Nine Inch Nails"), released in 2000, references "You're So Vain", by quoting the chorus.
  * Supporters of English football team [Everton F.C.](/wiki/Everton_F.C. "Everton F.C.") sang the song to player [Leighton Baines](/wiki/Leighton_Baines "Leighton Baines") at the 2009 football matches.[36][37]
  * On their 2009 album _[Felony](/wiki/Felony_\(album\) "Felony \(album\)")_ , [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") metalcore band [Emmure](/wiki/Emmure "Emmure") had a song titled "R2Deepthroat" where vocalist Frankie says "You're so vain, I bet you think this song is about you, don't you?"
  * In the lead-up to the [2016 US presidential election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United States presidential election, 2016"), Simon authorized the use of the song in an ad against [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump").[38]
  * In a piece posted by [BBC News](/wiki/BBC_News "BBC News") on May 5, 2017, Simon sings a previously unreleased fourth verse to the song, which she states had been written on a pad some time ago but never made it into the song. It references a man, married multiple times, who "called her once to ask her things she couldn't quite divine".[39]
  * On the October, 3, 2017, episode of the reality television singing competition program _[The Voice](/wiki/The_Voice_\(U.S._series\) "The Voice \(U.S. series\)")_ , Karli Webster performed a shortened version of the song for a Blind Audition, which turned the chairs of prospective coaches [Adam Levine](/wiki/Adam_Levine "Adam Levine") and [Miley Cyrus](/wiki/Miley_Cyrus "Miley Cyrus"). (The full version of Webster's rendition, even today, is available for purchase and download on [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes").) Webster ultimately chose Cyrus as her coach and joined Team Miley.

## Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27re_So_Vain&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

The song was a number-one hit in the US, Canada and Australia and reached
number four in Ireland and South Africa.[40] Bowing at #99 on the [_Billboard_
Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") on 2 December 1972, the
song took only five more weeks to rocket to the top of the chart, where it
stayed for the first three weeks of 1973, also spending two weeks at the top
of the [Easy Listening](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult Contemporary
\(chart\)") chart in early 1973, her first number one on either chart. "You're
So Vain" was Simon's breakthrough hit in the United Kingdom, reaching number
three on the UK chart on its original release in 1973. The song was re-
released in the UK in 1991 to cash in on its inclusion in a commercial for
[Dunlop Tyres](/wiki/Dunlop_Tyres "Dunlop Tyres"), peaking at number 41.
